text: How often do you update drivers in the sledgehammer image?
<@UCU824PB2> which drivers are you thinking of?  by design, sledgehammer is very stable and minimal.
i40e
are you having issues w/ sledgehammer not using the NIC?

Not exactly. I'm seeing an inconsistent NIC naming. I have 2x25G XXV710 cards, which initially identify as eth4-7, Most of them get renamed to enpXXs0f[0,1] as expected, except for the first one, which stays eth4. I'm trying to figure out if it's a f/w issue, or a driver issue, and I notice that particular driver is about 2.1.14-k, while Intel's current build is 2.4.10
I can actually work around this particular one, since all I really care about is the lldp info I'm getting. It's just a minor inconvenience.
Is this all within sledgehammer or sledgehammer compared to an installed os?
within sledgehammer.

```<sledgehammer> [root@esx05-r02 ~]# ip link show
1: lo: <LOOPBACK,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 65536 qdisc noqueue state UNKNOWN mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/loopback 00:00:00:00:00:00 brd 00:00:00:00:00:00
2: eno1: <NO-CARRIER,BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state DOWN mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether e4:43:4b:04:b5:e8 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
3: eno2: <NO-CARRIER,BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state DOWN mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether e4:43:4b:04:b5:e9 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
4: eno3: <NO-CARRIER,BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state DOWN mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether e4:43:4b:04:b5:ea brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
5: eno4: <NO-CARRIER,BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state DOWN mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether e4:43:4b:04:b5:eb brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
6: eth4: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 3c:fd:fe:c2:6a:d0 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
7: enp59s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 3c:fd:fe:c2:6a:d1 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
8: enp135s0f0: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 3c:fd:fe:c2:74:70 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
9: enp135s0f1: <BROADCAST,MULTICAST,UP,LOWER_UP> mtu 1500 qdisc mq state UP mode DEFAULT group default qlen 1000
    link/ether 3c:fd:fe:c2:74:71 brd ff:ff:ff:ff:ff:ff
``` Look at line 6. I would expect that to be enp59s0f0

Maybe a stupid question and not directly referring to rackN, but I figured you guys might be the best to answer that. My friend is looking for a "cloud" offering with access to iPXE boot and serial console, do you know any?
Yeah.  I think that is a use issue.  I’m not sure the kernel renames in use devices.
That is for <@UCU824PB2>
<@UCUFH954J> - depending upon what your friend needs you might want to look at <http://Packet.net|Packet.net>.
They definitely do that as a “cloud” offering.
I'll let him know, thanks!
You're saying that because `eth4` is the primary interface it didn't get renamed?
good enough.
I think that is true.
<@UCU824PB2> `drpcli gohai` contains the StableName for every NIC.
I ran into the same issue and <@U6QFVRJNB> was kind enough to add this into gohai for me.
That's awesome. Thanks!
I think it was <@U02DJQSG8> that trued things up in the NIC naming - but happy that the change is useful :slightly_smiling_face:
<@UCU824PB2> Yes, interfaces that are in use cannot be renamed, and depending on Sledgehammer version nic renaming may happen after we have brought the interface we PXE booted up.
<@U6QFVRJNB>, you're right it was <@U02DJQSG8> :slightly_smiling_face: Thanks again <@U02DJQSG8>
That seems to be the case here. Thanks for the info, <@U02DJQSG8>
